body.p:
Flemingsburg Novr. 12th 1863
To His Excellency Thomas E. Bramlett
Governor of Kentucky
Sir.

Diana Pitt, Spinster, was fined at the last September term of the Fleming Circuit Court Sixty dollars and costs on an Indictment for keeping a tippling house- and not having any property subject to execution is now confined in the jail of county at county expense on a capias pro fine. She is an unmarried woman but has managed to have several children-the youngest only about six months old. She has been in jail several days and there is no probability that she can give security; and will, unless the fine is remitted have to remain for thirty days. We think that there is no public good to be attained by confining her longer in jail-and it will increase the county expense. The judgment so far as it could influence her future conduct has done all it can do. We therefore respectfully ask your excellency to remit So much of said fine as you constitutionally and legally can remit, and pardon and remit all the imprisonment annexed to the fine. We respectfully ask your immediate action on this matter

Your Obedient
Servants
Leander M. Cox
Wm H. Cord
County attorney.
John M. Harbeson
M. L. Harbeson
P. S. If you remit mail to clerk of the court J. M. Harbeson Esq.

Fleming County
Remission
Refused
Tho E Bramlette
63
